Here is the modified document:

> summary(fit)
Coefficients:
Estimate Standard Error z value P-value
(Intercept) 0.256 0.432 0.59 0.55
X1 7.78 4.09 1.90 0.057 *
X2 9.81 5.66 1.73 0.083 .
X3 -8.14 5.50 -1.48 0.139
X4 0.019 6.00 0.003 0.998
X5 -5.18 3.89 -1.33 0.183
X6 9.48 4.65 2.04 0.042 *

Signif. codes: 
*** p < 0.001, ** p < 0.01, * p < 0.05, . p < 0.1

Figure 1: Excerpt from an object of class "glm" obtained by fitting a logistic model in R.
The coefficient estimates β^j are obtained by maximum likelihood estimation,
and for each variable, R provides an estimate of the standard deviation of β^j
as well as a p-value for testing whether βj = 0 or not.

1. Fitting a model via maximum likelihood produces estimates that are approximately unbiased and represent the most likely value given the data.
2. There are established formulas to predict the accuracy or variability of the maximum-likelihood estimate (MLE), which can be used to assess the reliability of the results.
